A Practical Introduction for Full-Stack Web Developers
- Node.js is a runtime environment that lets you run JavaScript code
- Built on Chrome’s V8 JavaScript engine.
- Created to build scalable network applications.
- Enables full-stack JavaScript development (same language on client
- Allows running JavaScript scripts directly from the command line.
- npm is the default package manager that comes with Node.js.
- Used to install, share, and manage millions of third-party packages
- Also used to manage project dependencies and scripts via
- Makes it easy to add features without having to build everything
- Automatically manages and installs nested dependencies.
- Allows defining and running project-specific scripts like start, test, or

tspan.tspan: Module usage in our script (e.g. file

text.tspan: - npm init -y → initializes a new Node.js project in the current
directory by creating a package.json file with default settings.
Modules that come built into Node.js
Node.js includes built-in modules (also called core modules).
Being already included implies that you don't need to install them but just
have to require them in the code.
- fs (File System) - Used to read from and write to the file system (create,
- http (HTTP Server) - Used to create web servers and handle HTTP
- path (File Path Utilities) - Provides utilities to work with file and
directory paths in a cross-platform way.
- os (Operating System) - Info Gives information about the system, like
- Use Postman. curl or browser to test routes.
- You can implement CRUD with GET, POST, PUT, DELETE.
Middleware are functions with access to req, res, and next.
Used for logging, auth, error handling, etc.
Keep secrets like API keys out of code.
The basics of HTTP in Node.js
Express is a minimal web framework for Node.js.
- Non-blocking, event-driven architecture → great for I/O-heavy tasks.
- Fast execution thanks to the V8 engine.
- One language for frontend and backend.
